section.heading: Jurisdiction of offense committed in State.

content.p: Every person, whether an inhabitant of this state, or any other state, or of a territory or district of the United States, is liable to punishment by the laws of this state for a public offense committed therein, except where it is by law cognizable exclusively in the courts of the United States.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 58; RL ï¿½ 6908; NCL ï¿½ 10705]

section.heading: Jurisdiction of offense commenced without, but consummated within, this State; consummation through agent.

content.p: When the commission of a public offense, commenced without the State, is consummated within its boundaries, the defendant is liable to punishment therefor in this State, though the defendant was out of the State at the time of the commission of the offense charged. If the defendant consummated it in this State, through the intervention of an innocent or guilty agent, or any other means proceeding directly from the defendant, in such case the jurisdiction is in the county in which the offense is consummated.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 59; RL ï¿½ 6909; NCL ï¿½ 10706]

section.heading: Act within this State culminating in crime in this or another state.

content.p: Whenever a person, with intent to commit a crime, does any act within this State in execution or part execution of such intent, which culminates in the commission of a crime, either within or without this State, such person is punishable for such crime in this State in the same manner as if the same had been committed entirely within this State.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 59a; added1927, 87; NCL ï¿½ 10707]

section.heading: Death by dueling.

content.p: When an inhabitant or resident of this state, by previous appointment or engagement, fights a duel or is concerned as second therein, out of the jurisdiction of this state, and in the duel a wound is inflicted upon a person, whereof the person dies in this state, the jurisdiction of the offense is in the county where the death happens.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 60; RL ï¿½ 6910; NCL ï¿½ 10708]

section.heading: Offense committed partly in one county and partly in another.

content.p: When a public offense is committed in part in one county and in part in another or the acts or effects thereof constituting or requisite to the consummation of the offense occur in two or more counties, the venue is in either county.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 61; RL ï¿½ 6911; NCL ï¿½ 10709]—(NRS A1963, 47)

section.heading: Offense committed on or near boundary.

content.p: When an offense is committed on the boundary of two or more counties, or within 500 yards thereof, the venue is in either county.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 62; RL ï¿½ 6912; NCL ï¿½ 10710]—(NRS A1963, 47)

section.heading: Offense committed on vessel in state waters, common carrier or private motor vehicle or aircraft.

content.p: On board a vessel navigating a river, slough, lake or canal, or lying therein, in the prosecution of a voyage, the venue is in any county through which the vessel is navigated in the course of the voyage, or in the county where the voyage terminates; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On a railroad train, car, stage or other public conveyance, or on a private motor vehicle, prosecuting its trip, the venue is in any county through which the train, car, stage or other public conveyance, or private motor vehicle, passes in the course of its trip, or in the county where the trip terminates; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On an aircraft prosecuting its trip, the venue is in any county over which the aircraft passes in the course of its trip, or in the county where the trip terminates. However, venue under this subsection shall be only in a county over or into which the aircraft passes prior to the first landing of such aircraft after the crime is discovered by or reported to the person in charge of such aircraft.

section.heading: Offenses concerning animals ranging in two or more counties.

content.p: When a public offense concerns any neat cattle, horse, mule or other animal running at large upon any range which extends into more than one county of this state, such offense may be prosecuted in either of the counties, and, upon the trial of any such offense, proof that such animal is the property of the owner, or person occupying the range, and was at the time the offense was committed running at large upon the range, shall be prima facie evidence that the offense was committed within the jurisdiction of the court.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 64; RL ï¿½ 6914; NCL ï¿½ 10712]

section.heading: Bigamy and incest.

content.p: When the offense, either of bigamy or incest, is committed in one county and the defendant is apprehended in another, the venue is in either county.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 66; RL ï¿½ 6916; NCL ï¿½ 10714]—(NRS A1963, 47)

section.heading: Burglary, robbery, larceny or embezzlement: Venue when property is taken in one county and brought into another.

content.p: When property taken in one county by burglary, robbery, larceny or embezzlement has been brought into another, the venue of the offense is in either county, but if, at any time before the conviction of the defendant in the latter, the defendant is indicted in the former county, the sheriff of the latter county must, upon demand, deliver the defendant to the sheriff of the former.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 67; RL ï¿½ 6917; NCL ï¿½ 10715]—(NRS A1963, 47)

section.heading: Accessory: Venue in either county where offense of accessory was committed or where principal offense committed.

content.p: In the case of an accessory in the commission of a public offense, the venue is in either the county where the offense of the accessory was committed, or where the principal offense was committed.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 68; RL ï¿½ 6918; NCL ï¿½ 10716]—(NRS A1963, 48)

section.heading: Conviction or acquittal in another state or territory is bar where jurisdiction is concurrent.

content.p: When an act charged as a public offense is within the jurisdiction of another state or territory, as well as of this state, a conviction or acquittal thereof in the former is a bar to the prosecution or indictment therefor in this state.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 Cr. Prac. ï¿½ 69; RL ï¿½ 6919; NCL ï¿½ 10717]—(NRS A2009, 2734)

section.heading: Conviction or acquittal in another county is bar where venue is concurrent.

content.p: When an offense is within the venue of two or more counties, a conviction or acquittal thereof in one county is a bar to the prosecution or indictment therefor in another.

section.heading: Enactment.

content.p: The California-Nevada Compact for Jurisdiction on Interstate Waters, set forth in full inNRS 171.077, is hereby enacted into law.

section.heading: Text of Compact. [Effective until proclamation by the Governor of this State of the enactment by the State of California of amendments that are substantially similar to the Compact, as amended by section 2 of chapter 82,Statutes of Nevada 2019, at page 447.]

content.p: The Legislature finds that law enforcement has been impaired in sections of Lake Tahoe and Topaz Lake forming an interstate boundary between California and Nevada because of difficulty in determining precisely where a criminal act was committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Legislature intends that a person committing an act which is illegal in both states not be freed merely because neither state could establish that a crime was committed within its boundaries. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The California-Nevada Compact for Jurisdiction on Interstate Waters is enacted to provide for enforcement of the laws of this state with regard to certain acts committed on Lake Tahoe or Topaz Lake, on either side of the boundary line between California and Nevada. ARTICLE II—Definitions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ As used in this compact, unless the context otherwise requires, ï¿½party stateï¿½ means a state which has enacted this compact. ARTICLE III—Concurrent Jurisdiction ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If conduct is prohibited by the party states, courts and law enforcement officers in either state who have jurisdiction over criminal offenses committed in a county where Lake Tahoe or Topaz Lake forms a common interstate boundary have concurrent jurisdiction to arrest, prosecute and try offenders for the prohibited conduct committed anywhere on the body of water forming a boundary between the two states. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This compact does not authorize: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prosecution of any person for conduct which is lawful in the state where it was committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any conduct prohibited by a party state. ARTICLE IV—Ratification ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ This compact is ratified by enactment of the language of this compact, or substantially similar language expressing the same purpose, by the State of California and the State of Nevada.

section.heading: Enactment.

content.p: The Interstate Compact for Jurisdiction on the Colorado River, set forth in full inNRS 171.079, is hereby enacted into law.

section.heading: Text of Compact.

content.p: The Legislature finds that law enforcement has been impaired in sections of the Colorado River forming an interstate boundary because of difficulty in determining precisely where a criminal act was committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Legislature intends that a person committing an act which is illegal in both states not be freed merely because neither state could establish that a crime was committed within its boundaries. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Interstate Compact for Jurisdiction on the Colorado River is enacted to provide for enforcement of the laws of this State with regard to certain acts committed on the Colorado River, or any lake formed by or a part of the Colorado River, on either side of the boundary line with an adjoining state. ARTICLE II—Definitions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ As used in this Compact, unless the context otherwise requires, ï¿½party stateï¿½ means a state which has enacted this Compact. ARTICLE III—Concurrent Jurisdiction ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If conduct is prohibited by two adjoining party states, courts and law enforcement officers in either state who have jurisdiction over criminal offenses committed in a county where the Colorado River, or any lake formed by or a part of the Colorado River, forms a common interstate boundary have concurrent jurisdiction to arrest, prosecute and try offenders for the prohibited conduct committed anywhere on the body of water forming a boundary between the two states and concurrent jurisdiction to arrest offenders for the prohibited conduct committed on any land mass within 5 air miles of the Colorado River or any lake formed by or a part of the Colorado River. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This Compact does not authorize: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prosecution of any person for conduct which is lawful in the state where it was committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any conduct prohibited by a party state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If any claim, including a counterclaim or cross-claim, is brought in a civil action which is filed in a party state and which is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Brought against a present or former officer or employee of another party state or an agency or political subdivision of that other party state; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Based on any alleged act or omission that is related to his or her official duties or employment and conducted under the authority of this Compact, ï¿½the claim is subject to the conditions and limitations on civil actions, including, without limitation, the provisions regarding sovereign immunity, established by the party state in which that officer or employee is or was an officer or employee. ARTICLE IV—Ratification ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ This Compact is ratified by enactment of the language of this Compact, or substantially similar language expressing the same purpose, by at least two states of which the Colorado River forms a common boundary.

section.heading: No statute of limitation for murder, sexual assault arising out of same facts and circumstances as murder or terrorism.

content.p: Murder, or a sexual assault arising out of the same facts and circumstances as a murder, must be commenced. It may be commenced at any time after the death of the person killed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation ofNRS 202.445must be commenced. It may be commenced at any time after the violation is committed.

section.heading: No limitation for sexual assault if identity of accused person is established by conducting genetic marker analysis of biological specimen and obtaining DNA profile.

content.p: If the identity of a person who is accused of committing a sexual assault is established by conducting a genetic marker analysis of a biological specimen and obtaining a DNA profile, the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085is removed and there is no limitation of the time within which a prosecution for the sexual assault must be commenced. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Biological specimenï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 176.09112. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½DNA profileï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 176.09115. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Genetic marker analysisï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 176.09118.

section.heading: No limitation for sexual assault or sex trafficking if written report filed with law enforcement officer during period of limitation; effect of disability on period of limitation.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 171.080, if, at any time during the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095, a victim of a sexual assault, a person authorized to act on behalf of a victim of a sexual assault, or a victim of sex trafficking or a person authorized to act on behalf of a victim of sex trafficking, files with a law enforcement officer a written report concerning the sexual assault or sex trafficking, the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095is removed and there is no limitation of the time within which a prosecution for the sexual assault or sex trafficking must be commenced. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a written report is filed with a law enforcement officer pursuant to subsection 1, the law enforcement officer shall provide a copy of the written report to the victim or the person authorized to act on behalf of the victim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a victim of a sexual assault or sex trafficking is under a disability during any part of the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095and a written report concerning the sexual assault or sex trafficking is not otherwise filed pursuant to subsection 1, the period during which the victim is under the disability must be excluded from any calculation of the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of this section, a victim of a sexual assault or sex trafficking is under a disability if the victim is insane, intellectually disabled, mentally incompetent or in a medically comatose or vegetative state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½law enforcement officerï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A prosecuting attorney; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An officer of a metropolitan police department or a police department of an incorporated city; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other person upon whom some or all of the powers of a peace officer are conferred pursuant toNRS 289.150to289.360, inclusive.

section.heading: Limitation for kidnapping or attempted murder extended if written report filed with law enforcement officer during period of limitation.

content.p: If, at any time during the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095, a victim of kidnapping or attempted murder, or a person authorized to act on behalf of such a victim, files with a law enforcement officer a written report concerning the offense, the period of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085and171.095is extended for 5 years. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a written report is filed with a law enforcement officer pursuant to subsection 1, the law enforcement officer shall provide a copy of the written report to the victim or the person authorized to act on behalf of the victim. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½law enforcement officerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 171.083.

section.heading: Limitations for felonies.

content.p: Theft, robbery, burglary, forgery, arson, a violation ofNRS 90.570, a violation punishable pursuant to paragraphs
to
, inclusive, of subsection 3 ofNRS 598.0999or a violation ofNRS 205.377must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 4 years after the commission of the offense. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Sexual assault must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 20 years after the commission of the offense. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Sex trafficking must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 6 years after the commission of the offense. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any felony other than the felonies listed in subsections 1, 2 and 3 must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 3 years after the commission of the offense.

section.heading: Limitations for gross and simple misdemeanors.

content.p: A gross misdemeanor must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 2 years after the commission of the offense. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other misdemeanor must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 1 year after the commission of the offense.

section.heading: Limitations for offenses committed in secret manner, offenses constituting sexual abuse or sex trafficking of child and offenses regarding personal identifying information.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2 andNRS 171.082,171.083and171.084: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a felony, gross misdemeanor or misdemeanor is committed in a secret manner, an indictment for the offense must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within the periods of limitation prescribed inNRS 171.085,171.090and624.800after the discovery of the offense, unless a longer period is allowed by paragraph
or
or the provisions ofNRS 202.885. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An indictment must be found, or an information or complaint filed, for any offense constituting sexual abuse of a child as defined inNRS 432B.100or sex trafficking of a child as defined inNRS 201.300, before the victim is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Thirty-six years old if the victim discovers or reasonably should have discovered that he or she was a victim of the sexual abuse or sex trafficking by the date on which the victim reaches that age; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Forty-three years old if the victim does not discover and reasonably should not have discovered that he or she was a victim of the sexual abuse or sex trafficking by the date on which the victim reaches 36 years of age. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a felony is committed pursuant toNRS 205.461to205.4657, inclusive, against a victim who is less than 18 years of age at the time of the commission of the offense, an indictment for the offense must be found, or an information or complaint filed, within 4 years after the victim discovers or reasonably should have discovered the offense. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If any indictment found, or an information or complaint filed, within the time prescribed in subsection 1 is defective so that no judgment can be given thereon, another prosecution may be instituted for the same offense within 6 months after the first is abandoned.

section.heading: Indictment found when it is presented and filed.

content.p: An indictment is found, within the meaning of this chapter, when it is presented by the grand jury in open court, and there received and filed.

section.heading: ï¿½No-knock warrantï¿½ defined.

content.p: Knocking on the door or ringing the doorbell and identifying the presence of the peace officer; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Identifying the presence of the peace officer and stating the intended purpose of the peace officer for entering the premises.

section.heading: Complaint defined; oath or declaration required.

content.p: Oath before a magistrate or a notary public; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Declaration which is made subject to the penalty for perjury.

section.heading: Court clerk may accept complaint filed electronically; procedure; service.

content.p: A court clerk may accept a complaint filed pursuant to this chapter that is filed electronically. A complaint that is filed electronically must contain an image of the signature of the prosecuting attorney. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a court clerk accepts a complaint that is filed electronically pursuant to subsection 1, the court clerk shall acknowledge receipt of the complaint by an electronic time stamp and shall electronically return the complaint with the electronic time stamp to the prosecuting attorney. A complaint that is filed and time-stamped electronically pursuant to this section may be converted into a printed document and served upon a defendant in the same manner as a complaint that is not filed electronically.

section.heading: Arrest defined; by whom made.

content.p: An arrest is the taking of a person into custody, in a case and in the manner authorized by law. An arrest may be made by a peace officer or by a private person.

section.heading: Issuance of warrant or summons upon application, complaint or citation; no-knock warrants.

content.p: If it appears from an affidavit or affidavits filed with an application for a warrant that there is probable cause to believe that an offense, triable within the county, has been committed and that the defendant has committed it, a warrant for the arrest of the defendant must be issued by the magistrate to any peace officer. Upon the request of the district attorney, a summons instead of a warrant must be issued. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If it appears from an affidavit or affidavits filed with a complaint or citation issued pursuant toNRS 484A.730,488.920or501.386that there is probable cause to believe that an offense, triable within the county, has been committed and that the defendant has committed it, the magistrate may issue to any peace officer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A warrant; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A summons. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A magistrate may not issue a warrant that is a no-knock warrant pursuant to subsection 1 or 2 unless an affidavit filed with the application, complaint or citation, as applicable: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Demonstrates that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The underlying offense: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Is punishable as a felony; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Involves a significant and imminent threat to public safety; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Identifying the presence of the peace officer before entering the premises is likely to create an imminent threat of substantial bodily harm to the peace officer or another person; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Describes with specificity the factual circumstances as to why there are no reasonable alternatives to effectuate the arrest of the defendant other than in the manner prescribed by the no-knock warrant; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

States whether the no-knock warrant can be executed during the day and, if it cannot, describes with specificity the factual circumstances that preclude the no-knock warrant from being executed during the day; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Certifies that the no-knock warrant will be executed under the guidance of a peace officer who is trained in the execution of warrants. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
More than one warrant or summons may be issued on the same application, complaint or citation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a defendant fails to appear in response to a summons, a warrant must be issued for the arrest of the defendant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A no-knock warrant issued pursuant to subsection 3 is void if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A peace officer deliberately misrepresents a material fact or deliberately omits material information in an affidavit in support of an application for the no-knock warrant; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the misrepresented material fact is excluded or the omitted material information is included, the affidavit does not meet the criteria set forth in paragraphs
to
, inclusive, of subsection 3.

section.heading: Contents of warrant of arrest.

content.p: Contain the name of the defendant or, if the defendantï¿½s name is unknown, any name or description by which the defendant can be identified with reasonable certainty; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
State the offense described inNRS 171.106; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Command that the defendant be arrested and brought before the nearest available magistrate; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
State whether the warrant is a no-knock warrant.

section.heading: Contents of summons.

content.p: A summons is an order in writing in the name of the State of Nevada which must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Include the information described in subsections 1 to 4, inclusive, ofNRS 171.108; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Summon the defendant to appear before a magistrate at a stated time and place. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon a complaint against a corporation, the magistrate must issue a summons, signed by the magistrate, with the magistrateï¿½s name of office, requiring the corporation to appear before the magistrate at a specified time and place to answer the charge, the time to be not less than 10 days after the issuing of the summons.

section.heading: Execution of warrant and service of summons: By whom.

content.p: The warrant shall be directed to and executed by a peace officer. The summons may be served by any person authorized to serve a summons in a civil action.

section.heading: When magistrate may depute person to act as constable.

content.p: A magistrate may depute in writing any suitable and discreet person to act as constable when no constable is at hand and the nature of the business requires immediate action.

section.heading: Execution of warrant and service of summons: Territorial limits.

content.p: The warrant may be executed or the summons may be served at any place within the jurisdiction of the State of Nevada.

section.heading: Manner in which execution of warrant and service of summons are made; additional requirements for execution of no-knock warrant; issuance of citation in lieu of execution of warrant of arrest.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, the warrant must be executed by the arrest of the defendant. The peace officer need not have the warrant in the peace officerï¿½s possession at the time of the arrest, but upon request the peace officer must show the warrant to the defendant as soon as possible. If the peace officer does not have a warrant in the peace officerï¿½s possession at the time of the arrest, the peace officer shall then inform the defendant of the peace officerï¿½s intention to arrest the defendant, of the offense charged, the authority to make it and of the fact that a warrant has or has not been issued. The defendant must not be subjected to any more restraint than is necessary for the defendantï¿½s arrest and detention. If the defendant either flees or forcibly resists, the peace officer may use only the amount of reasonable force necessary to effect the arrest as provided inNRS 171.1455and193.305. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to the requirements described in subsection 1, if the warrant is a no-knock warrant, the peace officers involved in the execution of the no-knock warrant shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Before executing the no-knock warrant, determine whether the circumstances necessitate that the arrest of the defendant be effectuated in the manner prescribed by the no-knock warrant and, if they do not, the peace officers shall not effectuate the arrest of the defendant in such a manner; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In executing the no-knock warrant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Use only the amount of force reasonably necessary to enter the premises; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As soon as practicable after entering the premises, identify the presence of the peace officers and state the purpose of the peace officers for entering the premises. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In lieu of executing a warrant by arresting the defendant, a peace officer may issue a citation as provided inNRS 171.1773if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The peace officer has no indication that the defendant has previously failed to appear on the charge reflected in the warrant; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The defendant signs a written promise to appear in court for the misdemeanor offense; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The peace officer has reasonable grounds to believe that the defendant will keep a written promise to appear in court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A summons must be served upon a defendant by delivering a copy to the defendant personally, or by leaving it at the defendantï¿½s dwelling house or usual place of abode with some person then residing in the house or abode who is at least 16 years of age and is of suitable discretion, or by mailing it to the defendantï¿½s last known address. In the case of a corporation, the summons must be served at least 5 days before the day of appearance fixed in the summons, by delivering a copy to an officer or to a managing or general agent or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process and, if the agent is one authorized by statute to receive service and the statute so requires, by also mailing a copy to the corporationï¿½s last known address within the State of Nevada or at its principal place of business elsewhere in the United States.

section.heading: Peace officer with limited jurisdiction must notify primary law enforcement agency of commission of certain felonies; transfer of investigation to primary law enforcement agency.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, in a county whose population is 100,000 or more, a peace officer with limited jurisdiction who witnesses a category A felony being committed or attempted in the officerï¿½s presence, or has reasonable cause for believing a person has committed or attempted to commit a category A felony in an area that is within the officerï¿½s jurisdiction, shall immediately notify the primary law enforcement agency in the city or county, as appropriate, where the offense or attempted offense was committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon arrival of an officer from the primary law enforcement agency notified pursuant to subsection 1, a peace officer with limited jurisdiction shall immediately transfer the investigation of the offense or attempted offense to the primary law enforcement agency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of subsection 1 do not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Apply to an officer of the Nevada Highway Patrol, a member of the police department of the Nevada System of Higher Education, an agent of the Investigation Division of the Department of Public Safety or a ranger of the Division of State Parks of the State Department of Conservation and Natural Resources; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Apply to a peace officer with limited jurisdiction if an interlocal agreement between the officerï¿½s employer and the primary law enforcement agency in the city or county in which a category A felony was committed or attempted authorizes the peace officer with limited jurisdiction to respond to and investigate the felony without immediately notifying the primary law enforcement agency; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prohibit a peace officer with limited jurisdiction from: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Contacting a primary law enforcement agency for assistance with an offense that is a misdemeanor, gross misdemeanor or felony that is not a category A felony; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Responding to a category A felony until the appropriate primary law enforcement agency arrives at the location where the felony was allegedly committed or attempted, including, without limitation, taking any appropriate action to provide assistance to a victim of the felony, to apprehend the person suspected of committing or attempting to commit the felony, to secure the location where the felony was allegedly committed or attempted and to protect the life and safety of the peace officer and any other person present at that location. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Peace officer with limited jurisdictionï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person employed to provide police services for an airport authority created by a special act of the Legislature; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A marshal or park ranger who is part of a unit of specialized law enforcement established pursuant toNRS 280.125. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Primary law enforcement agencyï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sheriffï¿½s office of a county; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the county is within the jurisdiction of a metropolitan police department, the metropolitan police department.

section.heading: Peace officer to provide information to suspected victims of domestic violence.

content.p: When investigating an act of domestic violence, a peace officer shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Make a good faith effort to explain the provisions ofNRS 171.137pertaining to domestic violence and advise victims of all reasonable means to prevent further abuse, including advising each person of the availability of a shelter or other services in the community. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provide a person suspected of being the victim of an act of domestic violence with a written copy of the following statements: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
My name is Officer ......................... (naming the investigating officer). Nevada law requires me to inform you of the following information. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If I have probable cause to believe that a battery has been committed against you, your minor child or the minor child of the person believed to have committed the battery in the last 24 hours by your spouse, your former spouse, any other person to whom you are related by blood or marriage, a person with whom you have had or are having a dating relationship or a person with whom you have a child in common, and if I had a face-to-face encounter with the person suspected of committing the battery that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service, I am required, unless mitigating circumstances exist, to arrest the person suspected of committing the battery. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If I have probable cause to believe that a battery has been committed against you, your minor child or the minor child of the person believed to have committed the battery in the last 7 days by your spouse, your former spouse, any other person to whom you are related by blood or marriage, a person with whom you have had or are having a dating relationship or a person with whom you have a child in common, and if I did not have a face-to-face encounter with the person suspected of committing the battery that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service, I am required, unless mitigating circumstances exist, to arrest the person suspected of committing the battery. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If I am unable to arrest the person suspected of committing the battery, you have the right to request that the prosecutor file a criminal complaint against the person. I can provide you with information on this procedure. If convicted, the person who committed the battery may be placed on probation, ordered to see a counselor, put in jail or fined. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The law provides that you may seek a court order for the protection of you, your minor children or any animal that is owned or kept by you, by the person who committed or threatened the act of domestic violence or by the minor child of either such person against further threats or acts of domestic violence. You do not need to hire a lawyer to obtain such an order for protection. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An order for protection may require the person who committed or threatened the act of domestic violence against you to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Stop threatening, harassing or injuring you or your children; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Move out of your residence; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Stay away from your place of employment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (IV) Stay away from the school attended by your children; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (V) Stay away from any place you or your children regularly go; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (VI) Avoid or limit all communication with you or your children; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (VII) Stop physically injuring, threatening to injure or taking possession of any animal that is owned or kept by you or your children, either directly or through an agent; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (VIII) Stop physically injuring or threatening to injure any animal that is owned or kept by the person who committed or threatened the act or his or her children, either directly or through an agent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A court may make future orders for protection which award you custody of your children and require the person who committed or threatened the act of domestic violence against you to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Pay the rent or mortgage due on the place in which you live; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Pay the amount of money necessary for the support of your children; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Pay part or all of the costs incurred by you in obtaining the order for protection; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (IV) Comply with the arrangements specified for the possession and care of any animal owned or kept by you or your children or by the person who committed or threatened the act or his or her children. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To get an order for protection, go to room number ....... (state the room number of the office at the court) at the court, which is located at ......................... (state the address of the court). Ask the clerk of the court to provide you with the forms for an order of protection. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the person who committed or threatened the act of domestic violence against you violates the terms of an order for protection, the person may be arrested and, if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) The arresting officer determines that such a violation is accompanied by a direct or indirect threat of harm; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The person has previously violated a temporary or extended order for protection; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) At the time of the violation or within 2 hours after the violation, the person has a concentration of alcohol of 0.08 or more in the personï¿½s blood or breath or an amount of a prohibited substance in the personï¿½s blood or urine, as applicable, that is equal to or greater than the amount set forth in subsection 3 or 4 ofNRS 484C.110, ï¿½the person will not be admitted to bail sooner than 12 hours after arrest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

You may obtain emergency assistance or shelter by contacting your local program against domestic violence at ......................... (state name, address and telephone number of local program) or you may call, without charge to you, the Statewide Program Against Domestic Violence at ........................ (state toll-free telephone number of Statewide Program). ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The failure of a peace officer to carry out the requirements set forth in subsection 1 is not a defense in a criminal prosecution for the commission of an act of domestic violence, nor may such an omission be considered as negligence or as causation in any civil action against the peace officer or the officerï¿½s employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Act of domestic violenceï¿½ means any of the following acts committed by a person against his or her spouse, former spouse, any other person to whom he or she is related by blood or marriage, a person with whom he or she has had or is having a dating relationship, a person with whom he or she has a child in common, the minor child of any of those persons or his or her minor child: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A battery. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An assault. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Compelling the other by force or threat of force to perform an act from which he or she has the right to refrain or to refrain from an act which he or she has the right to perform. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A sexual assault. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A knowing, purposeful or reckless course of conduct intended to harass the other. Such conduct may include, but is not limited to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Stalking. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Arson. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Trespassing. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (IV) Larceny. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (V) Destruction of private property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (VI) Carrying a concealed weapon without a permit. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (VII) Injuring or killing an animal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
False imprisonment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unlawful entry of the otherï¿½s residence, or forcible entry against the otherï¿½s will if there is a reasonably foreseeable risk of harm to the other from the entry. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Dating relationshipï¿½ means frequent, intimate associations primarily characterized by the expectation of affectional or sexual involvement. The term does not include a casual relationship or an ordinary association between persons in a business or social context.

section.heading: Peace officer to submit written report concerning suspected acts of domestic violence; information from reports to be aggregated and forwarded to Central Repository; content of report.

content.p: If a peace officer investigates an act that constitutes domestic violence pursuant toNRS 33.018, the peace officer shall prepare and submit a written report of the investigation to the peace officerï¿½s supervisor or to another person designated by the peace officerï¿½s supervisor, regardless of whether the peace officer makes an arrest. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the peace officer investigates a mutual battery that constitutes domestic violence pursuant toNRS 33.018and finds that one of the persons involved was the primary physical aggressor, the peace officer shall include in the report: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of the person who was the primary physical aggressor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A description of the evidence which supports the peace officerï¿½s finding. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the peace officer does not make an arrest, the peace officer shall include in the report the reason the peace officer did not do so. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The information contained in a report made pursuant to subsections 1 and 2 must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Aggregated each month; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Forwarded by each jurisdiction to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History not later than the 15th day of the following month. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Director of the Department of Public Safety shall prescribe the form on which the information described in subsection 4 must be reported to the Central Repository. In addition to the information required pursuant to subsections 1 and 2, the form must also require the inclusion of the following information from each report: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The relationship of the persons involved; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date and time of day of the offense; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Whether or not any person was given a domestic violence card that contains information about appropriate counseling or other supportive services available in the community in which that person resides; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether or not the primary physical aggressor, if identified, was arrested and, if not, any mitigating circumstances explaining why an arrest was not made; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether or not any other person was arrested.

section.heading: Investigation of alleged sexual offense: Alleged victim not required to submit to polygraphic examination or other similar examination.

content.p: A law enforcement officer, prosecutor or other employee of a governmental entity shall not, as a condition of investigating an alleged sexual offense, request or require a victim of the alleged sexual offense to take or submit to a polygraphic examination or other similar examination that is used, or the results of which are used, for the purpose of rendering a diagnostic opinion regarding the honesty or dishonesty of a person. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½sexual offenseï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 179D.097.

section.heading: Fingerprinting of persons detained and cited for committing suspected acts of domestic violence; fingerprints to be forwarded to Central Repository.

content.p: Detains a person for violating a county, city or town ordinance or state law that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is punishable as a misdemeanor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Constitutes domestic violence pursuant toNRS 33.018; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Issues the person a citation in lieu of taking the person before a magistrate, ï¿½the peace officer shall, in the manner prescribed by the Director of the Department of Public Safety, obtain a complete set of fingerprints of the person and forward those fingerprints and the report that the peace officer is required to prepare pursuant toNRS 171.1227to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History.

section.heading: Temporary detention by peace officer of person suspected of crime or civil infraction or of violating conditions of parole or probation: Limitations.

content.p: Any peace officer may detain any person whom the officer encounters under circumstances which reasonably indicate that the person has committed, is committing or is about to commit a crime or civil infraction. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any peace officer may detain any person the officer encounters under circumstances which reasonably indicate that the person has violated or is violating the conditions of the personï¿½s parole or probation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The officer may detain the person pursuant to this section only to ascertain the personï¿½s identity and the suspicious circumstances surrounding the personï¿½s presence abroad. Any person so detained shall identify himself or herself, but may not be compelled to answer any other inquiry of any peace officer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person must not be detained longer than is reasonably necessary to effect the purposes of this section, and in no event longer than 60 minutes. The detention must not extend beyond the place or the immediate vicinity of the place where the detention was first effected, unless the person is arrested. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½civil infractionï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 481.015.

section.heading: Arrest if probable cause appears.

content.p: At any time after the onset of the detention pursuant toNRS 171.123, the person so detained shall be arrested if probable cause for an arrest appears. If, after inquiry into the circumstances which prompted the detention, no probable cause for arrest appears, such person shall be released.

section.heading: Search to ascertain presence of dangerous weapon; seizure of weapon or evidence.

content.p: If any peace officer reasonably believes that any person whom the peace officer has detained or is about to detain pursuant toNRS 171.123is armed with a dangerous weapon and is a threat to the safety of the peace officer or another, the peace officer may search such person to the extent reasonably necessary to ascertain the presence of such weapon. If the search discloses a weapon or any evidence of a crime, such weapon or evidence may be seized. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Nothing seized by a peace officer in any such search is admissible in any proceeding unless the search which disclosed the existence of such evidence is authorized by and conducted in compliance with this section.

section.heading: Recording of law enforcement activity.

content.p: A person who is not under arrest or in the custody of a peace officer may record a law enforcement activity and maintain custody and control of that recording and any property or instruments used by the person to record a law enforcement activity. A person who is under arrest or in the custody of a peace officer does not, by that status alone, forfeit the right to have any such recordings, property or instruments maintained and returned to him or her. This subsection must not be construed to authorize a person to engage in actions that interfere with or obstruct a law enforcement activity or otherwise violate any other law in an effort to record a law enforcement activity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A peace officer shall not act to interfere with a personï¿½s recording of a law enforcement activity, including, without limitation, by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Commanding that the person cease recording a law enforcement activity when the person was nevertheless authorized by law to record the law enforcement activity; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Stopping, seizing or searching the person because he or she recorded a law enforcement activity; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unlawfully seizing property or instruments used by the person to record a law enforcement activity, unlawfully destroying or seizing any recorded image of a law enforcement activity or copying such a recording of a law enforcement activity without the consent of the person who recorded it or obtaining approval from an appropriate court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Law enforcement activityï¿½ means any activity by a peace officer acting under the color of law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Peace officerï¿½ means any person upon whom some or all of the powers of a peace officer are conferred pursuant toNRS 289.150to289.360, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Recordï¿½ means to capture or attempt to capture any moving or still image, sound or impression through the use of any recording device, camera or any other device capable of capturing audio or moving or still images, or by means of written notes or observations. The term includes, without limitation, the capturing of or the attempt to capture any moving or still image, sound or impression through the use of any such device for the purpose of broadcasting an event or occurrence in real time.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by2020, 32nd Special Session, 68)

section.heading: Gaming licensee may detain person suspected of having committed felony in gaming establishment.

content.p: As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Establishmentï¿½ means any premises whereon any gaming is done or any premises owned or controlled by a licensee for the purpose of parking motor vehicles owned or operated by patrons of such licensee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Licenseeï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 463.0171. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents may take into custody and detain any person when such licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents have reasonable cause to believe the person detained has committed a felony, whether or not in the presence of such licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Detention pursuant to this section shall be in the establishment, in a reasonable manner, for a reasonable length of time and solely for the purpose of notifying a peace officer. Such taking into custody and detention shall not render the licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents criminally or civilly liable for false arrest, false imprisonment, slander or unlawful detention unless such taking into custody and detention are unreasonable under all the circumstances. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

No licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents are entitled to the immunity from liability provided for in this section unless there is displayed in a conspicuous place in the establishment a notice in boldface type clearly legible and in substantially this form: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Any gaming licensee or the licenseeï¿½s officers, employees or agents who have reasonable cause to believe that any person has committed a felony may detain such person in the establishment for the purpose of notifying a peace officer.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1973, 1700; A2003, 20th Special Session, 15)

section.heading: Identification of suspect by live lineup, photo lineup or show-up: Law enforcement agencies to adopt policies and procedures governing use.

content.p: Each law enforcement agency shall adopt policies and procedures governing the use of live lineups, photo lineups and show-ups. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Live lineupï¿½ means an identification procedure in which a group of persons, including the suspect, is displayed to an eyewitness to determine whether the eyewitness identifies the suspect as the perpetrator of a crime. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Photo lineupï¿½ means an identification procedure in which an array of photographs, including a photograph of the suspect, is displayed to an eyewitness in hard copy or by digital image to determine whether the eyewitness identifies the suspect as the perpetrator of a crime. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Show-upï¿½ means an identification procedure in which the suspect appears individually for possible identification by the eyewitness as the perpetrator of a crime.

section.heading: Electronic recording of custodial interrogations conducted in place of detention; adoption of policies by law enforcement agency.

content.p: Each law enforcement agency in this State shall adopt detailed, written policies regarding the electronic recording of custodial interrogations that are conducted in a place of detention. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any policies adopted by a law enforcement agency pursuant to this section must be made available: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To all law enforcement officers employed by the law enforcement agency; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For public inspection during normal business hours. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any policies adopted by a law enforcement agency pursuant to this section must include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A requirement that, except as otherwise provided in any policy adopted pursuant to paragraph

, an electronic recording must be made of an entire custodial interrogation which is conducted in a place of detention if the person being interrogated is suspected of committing homicide as described inNRS 200.010to200.260, inclusive, or sexual assault as defined inNRS 200.366. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A requirement that, except as otherwise provided in any policy adopted pursuant to paragraph

, if a person being interrogated chooses to make or sign a written statement during the course of a custodial interrogation concerning a homicide as described inNRS 200.010to200.260, inclusive, or sexual assault as defined inNRS 200.366, the making and signing of the statement must be electronically recorded. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The circumstances in which all or a portion of a custodial interrogation is not required to be electronically recorded, including, without limitation, when: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An equipment malfunction prevents the electronic recording of the custodial interrogation in its entirety and replacement equipment is not immediately available. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The law enforcement officer conducting the custodial interrogation fails, in good faith, to record the interrogation because: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) He or she inadvertently fails to operate the recording equipment properly; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) The recording equipment malfunctions or stops recording without the law enforcement officerï¿½s knowledge. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
More than one custodial interrogation is being conducted simultaneously, thereby exceeding the available electronic recording capacity of the recording equipment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The person who is being or will be interrogated: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) Affirmatively asserts his or her desire to speak with law enforcement officers without being recorded; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Makes a statement spontaneously and not in response to a question asked during the custodial interrogation; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (III) Makes a statement during routine questioning during the process of his or her arrest; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (IV) Makes a statement at a time when the law enforcement officer conducting the interrogation is, in good faith, unaware of the personï¿½s involvement in a homicide as described inNRS 200.010to200.060, inclusive, a sexual assault as defined inNRS 200.366or an offense for which a custodial interrogation is otherwise required to be electronically recorded in accordance with the policies adopted pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At the time of the custodial interrogation, the law enforcement officer conducting the interrogation is, in good faith, unaware that the type of offense involved is a homicide as described inNRS 200.010to200.060, inclusive, a sexual assault as defined inNRS 200.366or an offense for which a custodial interrogation is otherwise required to be electronically recorded in accordance with the policies adopted pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Exigent circumstances make recording impractical. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requirements pertaining to the retention and storage of electronic recordings made pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The circumstances in which all or a portion of an electronic recording is not required to be retained, including, without limitation, when the electronic recording is damaged or destroyed, without bad faith on the part of any person or entity in control of the electronic recording. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each law enforcement agency in this State shall collaborate with the district attorney of the county in which the law enforcement agency is located regarding the contents of the policies required to be adopted pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Custodial interrogationï¿½ means any interrogation of a person who is required to be advised of his or her rights pursuant toMiranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436
. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Electronic recordingï¿½ means an audio or audiovisual recording. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Interrogationï¿½ means questioning which is initiated by a law enforcement officer or any words or actions on the part of a law enforcement officer, other than those which are ordinarily attendant to arrest and custody, that the officer should know are reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response from the person who is being questioned. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Law enforcement agencyï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sheriffï¿½s office of a county; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A metropolitan police department; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A police department of an incorporated city. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Place of detentionï¿½ means a fixed location under the control of a law enforcement agency of this State where persons are questioned about alleged crimes.

section.heading: Arrest by peace officer or officer of Drug Enforcement Administration.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3 andNRS 33.070and33.320, a peace officer or an officer of the Drug Enforcement Administration designated by the Attorney General of the United States for that purpose may make an arrest in obedience to a warrant delivered to him or her, or may, without a warrant, arrest a person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a public offense committed or attempted in the officerï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a person arrested has committed a felony or gross misdemeanor, although not in the officerï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a felony or gross misdemeanor has in fact been committed, and the officer has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On a charge made, upon a reasonable cause, of the commission of a felony or gross misdemeanor by the person arrested. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a warrant has in fact been issued in this State for the arrest of a named or described person for a public offense, and the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person arrested is the person so named or described. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A peace officer or an officer of the Drug Enforcement Administration designated by the Attorney General of the United States for that purpose may also, at night, without a warrant, arrest any person whom the officer has reasonable cause for believing to have committed a felony or gross misdemeanor, and is justified in making the arrest, though it afterward appears that a felony or gross misdemeanor has not been committed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An officer of the Drug Enforcement Administration may only make an arrest pursuant to subsections 1 and 2 for a violation ofchapter 453of NRS.

section.heading: Arrest by agent of Federal Bureau of Investigation or Secret Service.

content.p: For a public offense committed or attempted in the agentï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a person arrested has committed a felony or gross misdemeanor, although not in the agentï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a felony or gross misdemeanor has in fact been committed, and the agent has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On a charge made, upon a reasonable cause, of the commission of a felony or gross misdemeanor by the person arrested. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a warrant has in fact been issued in this State for the arrest of a named or described person for a public offense, and the agent has reasonable cause to believe that the person arrested is the person so named or described.

section.heading: Arrest by officer or agent of Bureau of Indian Affairs or police officer employed by Indian tribe.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, an officer or agent of the Bureau of Indian Affairs or a person employed as a police officer by an Indian tribe may make an arrest in obedience to a warrant delivered to him or her, or may, without a warrant, arrest a person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a public offense committed or attempted in the officer or agentï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a person arrested has committed a felony or gross misdemeanor, although not in the officer or agentï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a felony or gross misdemeanor has in fact been committed, and the officer or agent has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On a charge made, upon a reasonable cause, of the commission of a felony or gross misdemeanor by the person arrested. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a warrant has in fact been issued in this State for the arrest of a named or described person for a public offense, and the officer or agent has reasonable cause to believe that the person arrested is the person so named or described. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When the peace officer has probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has committed a battery upon that personï¿½s spouse and the peace officer finds evidence of bodily harm to the spouse. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Such an officer or agent may make an arrest pursuant to subsection 1 only: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Within the boundaries of an Indian reservation or Indian colony for an offense committed on that reservation or colony; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Outside the boundaries of an Indian reservation or Indian colony if the officer or agent is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Acting under an agreement pursuant to subsection 3 ofNRS 289.152; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In fresh pursuit of a person who is reasonably believed by the officer or agent to have committed a felony within the boundaries of the reservation or colony or has committed, or attempted to commit, any criminal offense within those boundaries in the presence of the officer or agent. ï¿½For the purposes of this subsection, ï¿½fresh pursuitï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 171.156.

section.heading: Arrest by postal inspector of United States Postal Inspection Service.

content.p: A postal inspector of the United States Postal Inspection Service may make an arrest in obedience to a warrant delivered to him or her, or may, without a warrant, arrest a person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For a public offense related to postal matters committed or attempted in the postal inspectorï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the person arrested has committed a felony or gross misdemeanor related to postal matters, although not in the postal inspectorï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a felony or gross misdemeanor related to postal matters has in fact been committed, and the postal inspector has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
On a charge made, upon a reasonable cause, of the commission of a felony or gross misdemeanor related to postal matters by the person arrested. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

When a warrant has in fact been issued in this State for the arrest of a named or described person for a public offense related to postal matters, and the postal inspector has reasonable cause to believe that the person arrested is the person so named or described. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½postal mattersï¿½ means any act related to mail service, including, without limitation, delivering and collecting mail, mail theft and mail fraud.

section.heading: Arrest by private person.

content.p: For a public offense committed or attempted in the personï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the person arrested has committed a felony, although not in the personï¿½s presence. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When a felony has been in fact committed, and the private person has reasonable cause for believing the person arrested to have committed it.

section.heading: Magistrate may order arrest for committing or attempting to commit offense in magistrateï¿½s presence.

content.p: A magistrate may orally order a peace officer or private person to arrest anyone committing or attempting to commit a public offense in the presence of the magistrate, and may thereupon proceed as if the offender had been brought before the magistrate on a warrant of arrest.

section.heading: Person making arrest may summon assistance.

content.p: Any person making an arrest may orally summon as many persons as the person making the arrest deems necessary to aid him or her therein.

section.heading: Escape or rescue of arrested person: Pursuit and retaking at any time and place in State.

content.p: If a person arrested escapes or is rescued, the person from whose custody he or she escaped or was rescued may immediately pursue and retake the person at any time and in any place within the State.

section.heading: When arrest may be made.

content.p: If the offense charged is a felony or gross misdemeanor, the arrest may be made on any day, and at any time of day or night. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If it is a misdemeanor, the arrest cannot be made between the hours of 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., except: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the person is found and the arrest is made in a public place or a place that is open to the public and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
There is a warrant of arrest against the person; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The misdemeanor is discovered because there was probable cause for the arresting officer to stop, detain or arrest the person for another alleged violation or offense; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the offense is committed in the presence of a private person and the person makes an arrest immediately after the offense is committed; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the person is already in custody as a result of another lawful arrest; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
When the person voluntarily surrenders himself or herself in response to an outstanding warrant of arrest.

section.heading: Arrest required for suspected battery constituting domestic violence; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, whether or not a warrant has been issued, a peace officer shall, unless mitigating circumstances exist, arrest a person when the peace officer has probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has committed a battery upon his or her spouse, former spouse, any other person to whom he or she is related by blood or marriage, a person with whom he or she has had or is having a dating relationship, a person with whom he or she has a child in common, the minor child of any of those persons, his or her minor child or a person who is the custodian or guardian of his or her minor child: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the peace officer had a face-to-face encounter with the person to be arrested that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service, within the preceding 24 hours. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the peace officer did not have a face-to-face encounter with the person to be arrested that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service, within the preceding 7 days. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the peace officer has probable cause to believe that a battery described in subsection 1 was a mutual battery, the peace officer shall attempt to determine which person was the primary physical aggressor. If the peace officer determines that one of the persons who allegedly committed a battery was the primary physical aggressor involved in the incident, the peace officer is not required to arrest any other person believed to have committed a battery during the incident. In determining whether a person is a primary physical aggressor for the purposes of this subsection, the peace officer shall consider: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The potential for future injury; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether one of the alleged batteries was committed in self-defense; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other factor that may help the peace officer decide which person was the primary physical aggressor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A peace officer shall not base a decision regarding whether to arrest a person pursuant to this section on the peace officerï¿½s perception of the willingness of a victim or a witness to the incident to testify or otherwise participate in related judicial proceedings. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability upon a peace officer or his or her employer for a determination made in good faith by the peace officer not to arrest a person pursuant to this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Siblings, except those siblings who are in a custodial or guardianship relationship with each other; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Cousins, except those cousins who are in a custodial or guardianship relationship with each other. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½dating relationshipï¿½ means frequent, intimate associations primarily characterized by the expectation of affectional or sexual involvement. The term does not include a casual relationship or an ordinary association between persons in a business or social context.

section.heading: Arrest of person suspected of battery upon certain persons.

content.p: Whether or not a warrant has been issued, a peace officer may arrest a person if the peace officer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has, within the preceding 24 hours, committed a battery upon: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A sibling, if the person is not the custodian or guardian of the sibling; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A cousin, if the person is not the custodian or guardian of the cousin; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Had a face-to-face encounter with the person to be arrested that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Whether or not a warrant has been issued, a peace officer may arrest a person if the peace officer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has, within the immediately preceding 7 days, committed a battery upon: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A sibling, if the person is not the custodian or guardian of the sibling; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A cousin, if the person is not the custodian or guardian of the cousin; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Did not have a face-to-face encounter with the person to be arrested that was of sufficient duration to determine whether probable cause existed while responding to the initial incident or call for service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability upon a peace officer or his or her employer for a determination made in good faith by the peace officer not to arrest a person pursuant to this section.

section.heading: Breaking open door or window: Making arrest.

content.p: To make an arrest, a private person, if the offense is a felony, and in all cases a peace officer, may break open a door or window of the house, structure or other place of concealment in which the person to be arrested is, or in which there is reasonable grounds for believing the person to be, after having demanded admittance and explained the purpose for which admittance is desired.

section.heading: Breaking open door or window: Upon detention after making arrest.

content.p: Any person who has entered a house, structure or other place of concealment to make an arrest may break open a door or window if that is necessary to liberate himself or herself. An officer may do the same to liberate a person who, acting in the officerï¿½s aid, entered to make an arrest and is detained inside.

section.heading: Breaking open door or window: Retaking person arrested.

content.p: To retake a person arrested who has escaped or been rescued, the person pursuing may break open an outer or inner door or window of a dwelling house, structure or other place of concealment, if, after notice of his or her intention, the person pursuing is refused admittance.

section.heading: Use of deadly force to effect arrest: Limitations.

content.p: A peace officer shall use de-escalation techniques and alternatives to the use of force whenever possible or appropriate and consistent with his or her training, including, without limitation, advisements, warnings, verbal persuasion and other tactics. If it is necessary for the peace officer to use force, the peace officer must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If it is possible to do so safely, identify himself or herself as a peace officer through verbal commands, visual identification, including, without limitation, a clearly marked uniform or vehicle, or other reasonable means; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Use only the level of force that is objectively reasonable under the circumstances to bring an incident or person under control and safely accomplish a lawful purpose. The level of force used by the officer must, to the extent feasible: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be balanced against the level of force or resistance exhibited by the person; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be carefully controlled. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A peace officer may, after giving a warning, if feasible, use deadly force to effect the arrest of a person only if there is probable cause to believe that the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has committed a felony which involves the infliction or threat of serious bodily harm or the use of deadly force; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Poses an imminent threat of serious bodily harm or death to the peace officer or to others. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Each law enforcement agency shall adopt a written policy and provide training to a peace officer regarding the potential threat of serious bodily harm or death to the peace officer or others from a person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is known or reasonably believed not to be armed with a deadly weapon; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is known or reasonably believed by the peace officer to be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Under 13 years of age; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Over 70 years of age; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Physically frail; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Mentally or physically disabled; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Pregnant; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Suffering from a mental or behavioral health issue; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Experiencing a medical emergency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The written policy adopted and training provided pursuant to subsection 3 must reflect the best practices with respect to the use of force on the persons described in that subsection. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In addition to any other information required pursuant to subsection 3, the written policy must include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Guidelines for the use of force; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Guidelines for the use of deadly force; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A requirement that peace officers utilize de-escalation techniques, crisis intervention and other alternatives to force when feasible; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A requirement that peace officers utilize de-escalation techniques for responding to persons with mental illness or experiencing a behavioral health crisis; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A requirement that the law enforcement agency, when feasible, send a peace officer who has been trained in crisis intervention to respond to an incident involving a person who has made suicidal statements; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Factors for evaluating and reviewing all incidents which require the use of force; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date on which the written policy was adopted by the law enforcement agency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
ï¿½Law enforcement agencyï¿½ means: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The sheriffï¿½s office of a county; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A metropolitan police department; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Department of Corrections; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any political subdivision of this State employing park rangers to enforce laws within its jurisdiction; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any political subdivision of this State which has as its primary duty the enforcement of law and which employs peace officers pursuant toNRS 289.150to289.360, inclusive, to fulfill its duty. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
